artist: Artist: George Cruikshank; Publisher: George Humphrey, London
creditline:
The Minnich Collection
The Ethel Morrison Van Derlip Fund, 1966
text: Cruikshank amusingly satirized the comical inelegance of a crowded drawing room, in this instance a royal reception given by Queen Charlotte at Buckingham Palace. He lampooned the participants with their absurd fashions and horrified, snooty expressions as awkward moments unfold. A contemporary had complained of the less-than-exclusive crowd attending the queen's drawing rooms: "The crowds are so great and so little decorum attended to, that people's clothes are literally torn to pieces."
title: Inconveniences of a Crowded Drawing Room
